greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of integer triangles with perimeter n which are acute and isosceles.
comment: Equivalently, the number of obtuse isosceles integer triangles with base n. - _Charlie Marion_, Jun 18 2019
link: Marius A. Burtea, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) = floor(n/2) - floor(n/(2 + sqrt(2))) - ((n + 1) mod 2). - _David Pasino_, Jun 27 2016
example: For n=9 there are A005044(9)=3 integer triangles: [1,4,4], [2,3,4] and [3,3,3]; both isosceles are also acute.
program: (MAGMA) [Floor(k/2)-Floor(k/(2 + Sqrt(2)))-((k + 1) mod 2): k in [1..76]]; // _Marius A. Burtea_, Jun 21 2019
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 05 2002
